sections.topic_name: INTRODUCTION
sections.summary: Human rights are universal, protected by law, and outlined in UN treaties, ECHR, and UK's Human Rights Act 1998.

sections.topic_name: As an international community, we have agreed that human rights are:
sections.summary: Human rights are universal, interdependent, equal, participatory, and empowering; governments must respect, protect, and fulfill these rights.

sections.topic_name: Absolute and non-absolute rights
sections.summary: The Human Rights Act includes absolute rights, which cannot be restricted, and non-absolute rights, which can be limited under specific conditions.

sections.topic_name: HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
sections.summary: UK rights are safeguarded by international, regional, and domestic laws, including the United Nations, Council of Europe, and Human Rights Act.

sections.topic_name: International human rights
sections.summary: The UDHR, adopted in 1948, establishes universal human rights, influencing subsequent treaties and covenants protecting these rights.

sections.topic_name: Regional
sections.summary: The UDHR inspired regional human rights covenants, including the ECHR, which the UK ratified, overseen by the European Court.

sections.topic_name: Domestic
sections.summary: The Human Rights Act integrates ECHR rights into UK law, establishing duties for public bodies and fostering a human rights culture.

sections.topic_name: OUR HUMAN RIGHTS ACT
sections.summary: Access BIHR's FAQs, Easy Read explainer, and video on the Human Rights Act for comprehensive information.

sections.topic_name: Article 2 - The right to life
sections.summary: The law shall protect everyone's right to life.

sections.topic_name: Article 3 - The right to be free from torture and inhuman and degrading treatment
sections.summary: Torture, inhuman treatment, and degrading punishment are prohibited for all individuals.

sections.topic_name: Article 4 - The right to be free from slavery and forced labour
sections.summary: No one shall be subjected to slavery or servitude.

sections.topic_name: Article 5 - The right to liberty
sections.summary: Everyone is entitled to liberty and personal security rights.

sections.topic_name: Article 6 - The right to a fair trial
sections.summary: Everyone has the right to a fair, public hearing by an independent, impartial tribunal within a reasonable timeframe.

sections.topic_name: Article 7 - The right not to be punished for something that wasn't against the law when you did it
sections.summary: No one can be guilty of a crime not defined at the time, nor face a heavier penalty.

sections.topic_name: Article 8 - The right to respect for private and family life, home and correspondence
sections.summary: Everyone is entitled to respect for their private and family life, home, and correspondence.

sections.topic_name: Article 9 - The right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion
sections.summary: The right encompasses freedom to change and manifest religion or belief, individually or communally, in public or private settings.

sections.topic_name: Article 10 - The right to freedom of expression
sections.summary: The right encompasses freedom to hold opinions and share information without public authority interference.

sections.topic_name: Article 11 - The right of freedom of assembly and association
sections.summary: Everyone has the right to peaceful assembly, association, and to form/join trade unions for personal interest protection.

sections.topic_name: Article 12 - The right to marry and start a family
sections.summary: Marriageable individuals have the right to marry and establish a family, as per national laws.

sections.topic_name: Article 14 - The right to be free from discrimination
sections.summary: Rights and freedoms in this Act are guaranteed without discrimination based on sex, race, religion, or other status.

sections.topic_name: Article 1, Protocol 1 - The right to peaceful enjoyment of possessions
sections.summary: Protocols outline rights to education, free elections, and abolition of the death penalty.

sections.topic_name: How the Human Rights Act works with other laws
sections.summary: Section 3 of the HRA mandates UK laws align with human rights, influencing decision-making and reducing legal challenges.

sections.topic_name: ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND CULTURAL RIGHTS
sections.summary: Economic, social, and cultural rights are essential for dignity; UK Government obligations often unmet, impacting accountability and domestic law.

sections.topic_name: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights: In Plain English
sections.summary: Trained on data until October 2023.

sections.topic_name: Article 1 - Self determination
sections.summary: Everyone has the right to self-determination and to decide their own destiny.

sections.topic_name: Article 2 - Duties and non-discrimination
sections.summary: The government must ensure equal economic, social, and cultural rights for all, using available resources and preventing discrimination.

sections.topic_name: Article 3 - Equality between men and women
sections.summary: Men and women have equal rights to economic, social, and cultural benefits.

sections.topic_name: Article 4 - Limiting rights
sections.summary: Government can limit rights legally, without undermining Covenant rights, to ensure fairness and protect others' rights.

sections.topic_name: Article 5 - Preserving rights and freedoms
sections.summary: The Covenant prohibits using its provisions to justify harming others' rights.

sections.topic_name: Article 6 - Right to work
sections.summary: Individuals have the right to work, choose their employment, and defend their rights; governments should provide education and training support.

sections.topic_name: Article 7 - Right to just and favourable conditions at work
sections.summary: Everyone has the right to fair wages, safe conditions, equal promotion opportunities, and paid holidays at work.

sections.topic_name: Article 8 - Trade union rights
sections.summary: Everyone can form trade unions for fair pay; government interference is limited, and striking is a right for fair treatment.

sections.topic_name: Article 9 - Right to social security
sections.summary: Governments must ensure social security systems provide financial or other support for those in need.

sections.topic_name: Article 10 - Protecting the family - especially mothers and children
sections.summary: Governments must protect families, ensure maternity leave, safeguard children from exploitation, and establish a minimum working age.

sections.topic_name: Article 11 - Right to an adequate standard of living
sections.summary: Everyone has the right to adequate living standards, quality of life, and freedom from hunger; governments must ensure these rights.

sections.topic_name: Article 12 - Right to health (physical and mental)
sections.summary: Governments must ensure health standards by reducing infant mortality, promoting healthy environments, preventing diseases, and providing accessible medical care.

sections.topic_name: Article 13 - Right to education
sections.summary: Education promotes personal development, rights awareness, societal participation; governments must ensure free primary, secondary, and higher education access.

sections.topic_name: Finally:
sections.summary: Parents can choose schools and their children's education, while anyone can establish schools meeting government standards.

sections.topic_name: Article 14 - Implementing free primary education
sections.summary: Governments must ensure compulsory and free primary education within two years of joining the Covenant.

sections.topic_name: Article 15 - Cultural rights
sections.summary: Governments must conserve, develop, and distribute science and culture while respecting research and artistic creation freedoms.

sections.topic_name: Article 25 - Using natural wealth and resources
sections.summary: The Covenant does not restrict peoples' rights to freely access and utilize their natural wealth and resources.

sections.topic_name: WHAT CAN RIGHTS DO FOR YOU?
sections.summary: Understanding and claiming rights empowers individuals to challenge unfair treatment despite systemic barriers and poverty in the UK.
